title: How My Skin Changed During Breast Cancer Treatment

content: When I think of this subject, it takes me back to when I was 15 or 16 years old. I was just learning about skin care because my face needed some extra TLC because of all the pimples I had. At the time, I wanted to find a magical soap or cream to help them all go away because I was embarrassed by how they were taking over my face. Of course, I didn’t really think about the hormonal changes in my body attributing to what was happening with my skin.

The very first thing I thought about when I was about to start chemotherapy and immunotherapy was the loss of my hair. All of my self-image thoughts were about my hair. Little did I know I would be wishing I could find that magic soap or cream to help me with my skin just like I did when I was younger. It wasn’t until a couple of weeks into treatment that I started noticing bumps on my skin. These bumps were pimple-like and were mostly on my cheeks and forehead. I also noticed I started to get painful bumps on my scalp and a lot of dryness. But it wasn’t just bumps on my face. No, my face was also covered in what I can only describe as pink and purplish tiny dots. These changes prompted me to address this with my oncologist.

My oncologist prescribed a cream called tretinoin, along with instructions on how to use it. After the cream didn’t work, I was referred to a dermatologist. I also took to my social media platform and asked for suggestions on natural home remedies for acne. Although there were many great suggestions, I landed on aloe-based products that alleviated some of the side effects like itchiness and pain. I did develop some pigmentation also known as "chemo freckles." Here are some of the things that helped my skin during this time:
bullets: Wash your pillowcases and sheets regularly.
Find a gentle face cleanser that will not dry out your skin.
Wash your face with warm water in the morning and before heading to bed.
Moisturizing is important. Find something suitable for your skin type. I really liked products from Lexli skin care.
Your diet is important. Remember that what you eat also affects your skin.

content: No matter what products you choose to use, make sure you let your dermatologist know in case they would like to see the ingredients to ensure there are no harsh chemicals or ingredients that can cause a negative reaction. There are also cancer support groups where you can also ask for suggestions or tips. So don’t be afraid to ask.
To connect with other breast cancer survivors, join our Breast Cancer Facebook Support Group .
